quotes.topic_title: Cold open: Steve Jobs elevator lore
quotes.text: ... those Steve Jobs' lore was that if you were in an elevator with him, you better be prepared to talk about what you do at the company because he had a habit of getting in the elevator and looking at you and saying, "What do you do? What do you do here?"
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Highlights a practical readiness principle: always be able to clearly and succinctly explain your role and impact.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: Steve Jobs elevator lore
quotes.text: And there were also rumors that people who had not given him a good answer, that ended up being their last day at Apple.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A vivid example of how high standards for clarity and accountability can be culturally enforced in elite organizations.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: Steve Jobs elevator lore
quotes.text: So there was someone who I didn't know personally but worked in my department before I got there who got in an elevator and looked up and Steve was approaching him and so he went to press the button to open the door and accidentally pressed the one to close the door.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Concrete story illustrating how intimidating “on-the-spot” leadership moments can be—and why preparation matters.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: Steve Jobs elevator lore
quotes.text: And apparently he got off and just bolted straight up, ran down the hallway.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Memorable anecdote showing the extreme lengths people may go to avoid high-pressure evaluation environments.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Camille is head of fan monetization at Spotify.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete focus area—fan monetization—as a key lever for creator-economy product strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: She started a company called Kit that she sold to Patreon.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific example of founder-to-acquisition trajectory that signals practical experience building and exiting in the creator tools space.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We chat about the future of creator platforms, how to be successful as a creator, and also as a new creator platform, the downsides of creator life plus frameworks, stories from Steve Jobs, ways to monetize being a creator and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets up the episode’s actionable scope: success tactics, platform-building considerations, monetization approaches, and frameworks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With one API, your team can add over 180 HR, accounting, ATS, ticketing, CRM, file storage and marketing automation integrations into your product.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A concrete scale/data point that reframes integrations as a leverage point rather than a long-tail engineering burden.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can get your first integration into production in a matter of days and save countless weeks building custom integrations, letting you get back to building your core product.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization advice: outsource undifferentiated integration work to focus engineering time on core product value.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Save your engineers countless hours, hit your growth targets, and expedite your sales cycle by making integration offerings your competitive advantage with Merge.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A practical go-to-market framing: treat integrations not as maintenance overhead but as a competitive advantage that accelerates sales.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If your team's work is spread out across different documents and spreadsheets and a stack of workflow tools, that's why you need Coda.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A diagnostic heuristic teams can apply to identify when tool sprawl is creating coordination costs and slowing execution.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Coda puts data in one centralized location regardless of format, eliminating roadblocks that can slow your team down.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A simple operating model for execution speed: centralize information across formats to reduce friction and unblock collaboration.

quotes.topic_title: Spotify fan monetization: merch and listening parties
quotes.text: As head of fan monetization, I have a team of folks who are really passionate about figuring out new ways to help artists and fans connect and also figure out ways to make those connections result in new monetization opportunities for the artists.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Defines a clear product mandate: design fan-artist connection loops that explicitly convert into monetization.

quotes.topic_title: Spotify fan monetization: merch and listening parties
quotes.text: But one of the things that we also know is it's not just the big huge superstars who have those rabid and super engaged fan bases. People are really passionate just about supporting the artists that they love in general.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Challenges the assumption that only top-tier artists can monetize fandom, implying monetization features should work for the long tail.

quotes.topic_title: Spotify fan monetization: merch and listening parties
quotes.text: And on Spotify, we want to figure out ways we can help that result in more money that goes directly to the artist.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Highlights a practitioner-oriented goal: optimize monetization mechanisms for direct artist revenue impact.

quotes.topic_title: Spotify fan monetization: merch and listening parties
quotes.text: So one of the ones that most mature is merch which is funny to say because most people probably don't realize that you can purchase merch on Spotify.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A concrete example that discoverability—not just product availability—can be the limiting factor in monetization.

quotes.topic_title: Spotify fan monetization: merch and listening parties
quotes.text: So things like an exclusive discount or an exclusive design or early access because you're a top listener on Spotify, really thinking about thank yous and rewards for your Spotify listenership and fandom.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Actionable playbook: tie rewards (discounts, exclusives, early access) to measurable engagement (e.g., top listener) to drive conversion.

quotes.topic_title: Working with artists: creativity and charging fans
quotes.text: But I think it takes an element of bravery, not to mention talent, but you really have to go out on a limb.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Highlights a practical mental model for creators: success requires risk-taking beyond raw skill.

quotes.topic_title: Working with artists: creativity and charging fans
quotes.text: I do think we saw this a lot at Patreon and I think you see it especially with musicians and artists, this feeling that you want to give your fans everything that you create and you want to do it for free because you're so enamored with this idea that people really love you and want to support you and they're really responding to your creativity and everything that you're making, you don't want to charge them. But what comes with that is, well, how are you going to make a living.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Surfaces the core monetization tension creators must resolve: generosity vs. sustainability.

quotes.topic_title: Working with artists: creativity and charging fans
quotes.text: To some degree, there has to be a value exchange that happens in order for a creative person to live from their art.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A clear, actionable principle for pricing and product design in creator businesses.

quotes.topic_title: Working with artists: creativity and charging fans
quotes.text: And we're really looking at it as a way to fans want to support the artists they love, they want to open up their wallets.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Reframes monetization as enabling fans’ desire to support, not extracting value from them.

quotes.topic_title: Working with artists: creativity and charging fans
quotes.text: You've see nothing else from a Substack and Patreons that people are actually really happy to be a patron of the arts and they look at it as like a badge of honor.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Points to a concrete market signal—membership platforms show fans often enjoy paying as identity and status.

quotes.topic_title: Creator monetization psychology and the content hamster wheel
quotes.text: It's funny because we live in a very capitalist and market dictate the price kind of society, but on an individual level, particularly when the commodity so to speak is art, there's so many emotions and feelings involved in that that it's hard for someone who's the creator to disassociate themselves from it and see what the market will bear.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Explains the psychological barrier creators face in pricing their work, highlighting why market pricing feels uniquely hard for art.

quotes.topic_title: Creator monetization psychology and the content hamster wheel
quotes.text: Which is why I actually think it's great that there's platforms who have stepped in and said, "Hey, we see an opportunity. Let us insert ourselves in the center, let us aggregate, and let us do the hard work of pricing and payment and tax and finance and actually create value where it would be really hard for an individual person who's a creator to do all of this work and facilitate that connection." It's almost like the perfect marketplace solution.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A marketplace mental model for why creator platforms win: they centralize the operational “hard parts” creators struggle to do alone.

quotes.topic_title: Creator monetization psychology and the content hamster wheel
quotes.text: one of the big downsides people don't think about with this life is once you start charging, people start buying, say, an annual subscription and that means I have to at least go for another year and in reality, I never really want to stop it because the revenue would just stop and that would be really sad. So you get on the treadmill where you don't really have an exit path.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A contrarian downside of subscriptions: monetization can lock creators into ongoing output with no clean off-ramp.

quotes.topic_title: Creator monetization psychology and the content hamster wheel
quotes.text: We call it internally the hamster wheel of content creation. You get on because you love it and then how do you get off.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A memorable label for the creator sustainability problem—continuous creation becomes hard to pause or exit once monetized.

quotes.topic_title: Creator monetization psychology and the content hamster wheel
quotes.text: So I have this lennybot.com site which is an AI chatbot based on all my content including the podcast episodes and actually, an engineer who was listening to this podcast reached out and offered to help me build it and he did and it's awesome.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of using existing content to build an AI product that could reduce the need for nonstop new creation.

quotes.topic_title: Where the creator economy is headed
quotes.text: I think it was probably predictable to some degree that platforms would win because just of the nature of aggregation. Once you have either all of the supply or you've aggregated the demand, it's really a strong network effect.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A durable mental model for why creator-economy startups struggle against incumbents: aggregation + network effects make winners hard to dislodge.

quotes.topic_title: Where the creator economy is headed
quotes.text: I wouldn't underestimate the strategic ability either of some the big platforms. They were definitely thinking ahead and building features and thinking about whether or not they saw it as a monetization opportunity.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A cautionary, practitioner-relevant reminder that incumbents actively preempt competition by shipping creator monetization features early.

quotes.topic_title: Where the creator economy is headed
quotes.text: So I'm in New York and last week, there was a mob and a riot because a Twitch streamer announced that he was going to be giving away PlayStations and computer gear in Union Square and something like a million teenage boys showed up. I'm not making this up. And they had to shut down the center of New York City to clear what turned into protest, riot, mob-
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A vivid real-world example of creator distribution power at scale—useful for internal buy-in on the impact of top creators.

quotes.topic_title: Where the creator economy is headed
quotes.text: There have been studies too where they ask young people what they want to do and what they want to be when they grow up, we quote these at, excuse me, Patreon and over 60% want to create content for a living.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A concrete data point indicating creator aspirations are mainstream and likely to keep fueling the ecosystem.

quotes.topic_title: Where the creator economy is headed
quotes.text: I think of Michelle Phan, right? She's basically a mini Disney and when you think of it like that, she's created IP. What can you do with IP? Comic books, movies, TV shows, plushies, merch.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A scalable framework for creator monetization: treat creators as IP engines and expand into multiple downstream formats and products.

quotes.topic_title: How creators succeed: consistency, collaboration, curation
quotes.text: One of the things that I've seen that I don't know if people realize is consistency and predictability of content creation which is where this idea that we were talking about earlier of a hamster wheel kind of comes on.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Highlights that predictable output—often dismissed as a “hamster wheel”—is a core, underappreciated driver of creator success.

quotes.topic_title: How creators succeed: consistency, collaboration, curation
quotes.text: But there is something to churning out consistent quality work and putting it out there for your audience to consume and respond and react to that goes a long way. It's almost like the 10,000 hours. You have to do 10,000 hours of something in order to truly master it.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Connects creator growth to deliberate repetition: consistent publishing compounds skill and audience feedback loops over time.

quotes.topic_title: How creators succeed: consistency, collaboration, curation
quotes.text: Another one is collaboration. So working with other great creators, sharing audience, exposing one another to those audiences, and then this was something we tried to employ at my startup, Kit. We would actually host events for creators to get together to facilitate meeting and cross pollination in the hopes that it would just benefit their careers.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Gives a concrete growth playbook—collaboration as audience cross-pollination—plus an operational tactic (hosting events) to make it happen.

quotes.topic_title: How creators succeed: consistency, collaboration, curation
quotes.text: There is a degree of having a brand, having something you stand for, having a vibe or an ethos and that person being almost, not a gatekeeper in a bad way, but like, "I, Camille, can't consume anywhere near all this content. You, I trust your vibe. Tell me what I should be listening to."
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Frames curators as trusted filters in an overload world, explaining why “vibe/ethos” and trust can outperform raw discovery.

quotes.topic_title: How creators succeed: consistency, collaboration, curation
quotes.text: Oftentimes, if it's your brother-in-law who's a great cyclist and they say, "Buy this," you just buy it. You don't even care what the reviews say because you trust that person.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A memorable example showing trust-based recommendations can beat anonymous reviews—useful for influencer/curation-driven distribution strategies.

quotes.topic_title: Kit startup story and selling to Patreon
quotes.text: We managed to raise some money, raised over $2 million, which is a huge accomplishment, especially if you know anything about venture capital.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A concrete fundraising data point that also sets expectations about how hard raising can be in venture capital.

quotes.topic_title: Kit startup story and selling to Patreon
quotes.text: They have a horrible track record when it comes to funding people of color, women, people who are non-cisgender white male, just the track record.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A blunt, countervailing reality check about structural funding dynamics that founders should plan around.

quotes.topic_title: Kit startup story and selling to Patreon
quotes.text: We were trying to raise Series A. We were, I think, early on the creator economy trend. Probably about a year and a half later, it would've been, I think, I hope a snap to raise money.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Highlights the timing risk in fundraising—being early to a trend can make capital harder even if the thesis is right.

quotes.topic_title: Kit startup story and selling to Patreon
quotes.text: And I actually did this startup accelerator called StartX that's run out of Stanford which is my alma mater. And we learned a lot about how to sell a company and what M&A looks like. So we started exploring that path.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Actionable takeaway: proactively learn the mechanics of M&A and explore acquisition as a deliberate strategic path, not a last resort.

quotes.topic_title: Kit startup story and selling to Patreon
quotes.text: And in the end, it made the most sense for us to have an exit and join forces with Patreon.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A simple decision criterion for M&A: choose the option that most clearly advances the company’s next chapter (e.g., via a strategic partner).

quotes.topic_title: Acquisition lessons: run a process, build relationships early
quotes.text: So I think that's one takeaway is treat it like a process and manage it like a process if it is something you're interested in. It doesn't really just... For most companies, I would say it doesn't just happen.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Frames selling a company as a deliberate, managed funnel (like fundraising) rather than a lucky inbound event.

quotes.topic_title: Acquisition lessons: run a process, build relationships early
quotes.text: And then the second piece of advice I would give I think we should have been talking to potential acquirers from the beginning and sharing our vision and what we were trying to accomplish because we started those quite late in our journey as a company and it just meant it took... When I met a potential CPO, who would acquire the company, who would end up being my boss or CEO, it was their first time meeting me whereas if it had been their fifth time, we would've had a relationship established and they would've known more about the vision and what we're trying to do and hopefully, would've had some more time to think about it.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Highlights the compounding advantage of building acquirer relationships early so the eventual deal isn’t a cold start.

quotes.topic_title: Acquisition lessons: run a process, build relationships early
quotes.text: Start preparing to sell your company from the moment you found it which is a weird thing because obviously, if you're starting a company, for most founders, they want it to be the next big thing, they're not starting it in order to sell it, but it's a good thing to have on your radar because you never know what the future holds.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance: plan for an acquisition from day one even if your intent is to build independently.

quotes.topic_title: Acquisition lessons: run a process, build relationships early
quotes.text: We sold our company the Airbnb and that's how it got to Airbnb and what I realized is you just need people who may buy you in the future to have you in their head when they have a problem so that they could be like, "Oh, Camille and her team could solve this problem for us. Let's go chat with her and-
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example plus a practical mental model: be top-of-mind for likely acquirers when their internal need arises.

quotes.topic_title: Acquisition lessons: run a process, build relationships early
quotes.text: Or if the meeting is not under the context of buying it all, it's like, "We're working on something cool. We have a great vision. It aligns with what you're doing. Maybe there's a partnership here," versus just tell you what we're doing and then when I contact you in 12 months about buying me, you've heard of me before.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Tactical approach to relationship-building: lead with partnership/vision now so acquisition conversations later aren’t awkward or cold.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace supply-side focus and why it matters
quotes.text: And in a marketplace like that where it's real time people trying to get a cab to go from uptown to downtown, you see the inexperience firsthand the impact to your business if you don't have suppliers, if your suppliers aren't happy, if they go on strike, if there's regulations that mean you can't use your service.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Concrete supply-side failure modes (unhappy suppliers, strikes, regulation) that can instantly break a real-time marketplace regardless of demand.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace supply-side focus and why it matters
quotes.text: And so we had to figure out how to launch that in the U.S., how to get drivers on how to create this supply and it was like it doesn't matter how nice the user experience is, how great the marketing is, how much demand you can generate if when someone opens that app, there are no cars available.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization: supply availability is the gating factor, so UX/marketing/demand gen won’t matter until supply is reliably present.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace supply-side focus and why it matters
quotes.text: So a lot of people talk about marketplaces as chicken and egg. I actually just think they're two-sided and you start with the supply and at the end of the day, you can optimize for the demand side or choose who you're going to prioritize in terms of if there's a conflict, we're going to pick this side or the other.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A reframing framework: marketplaces aren’t an abstract chicken-and-egg problem—start with supply and explicitly decide which side wins in conflicts.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace supply-side focus and why it matters
quotes.text: So I think that solidified my feeling that with marketplaces, you can't lose sight of the solving real pain points and needs for the supply side in order to make sure the entire business can operate.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Practical operating principle: continuously solve supplier pain points to keep the marketplace functioning end-to-end.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Thousands of fast-growing companies like Gusto, Comm, Quora, and Modern Treasury trust Vanta to help build, scale, manage, and demonstrate their security and compliance programs and get ready for audits in weeks, not months.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete outcome (audit readiness in weeks) and provides recognizable social proof that can guide vendor evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: By offering the most in-demand security and privacy frameworks such as SOC 2, ISO 27001, GDPR, HIPAA, and many more, Vanta helps companies obtain the reports they need to accelerate growth, build efficient compliance processes, mitigate risks to their businesses, and build trust with external stakeholders.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Connects compliance work to business outcomes (growth, risk mitigation, stakeholder trust) and names specific frameworks practitioners may need to prioritize.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 5,000 fast-growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2 and these other frameworks.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a specific adoption and automation data point that can inform expectations about how much compliance effort can be reduced.

quotes.topic_title: Apple and iTunes: early days and Steve Jobs encounter
quotes.text: Those Steve Jobs lore was that if you were in an elevator with him, you better be prepared to talk about what you do at the company because he had a habit of getting in the elevator and looking at you and saying, "What do you do? What do you do here?"
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A practical career/communication lesson: always be ready with a crisp explanation of your role and impact.

quotes.topic_title: Apple and iTunes: early days and Steve Jobs encounter
quotes.text: But I've always, in my family and in my life, had this encouragement to say hi to people when you see them and let them know that you appreciate what they do and just thank them because it doesn't happen often.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Actionable relationship-building guidance: proactively express appreciation rather than staying silent or only asking for something.

quotes.topic_title: Apple and iTunes: early days and Steve Jobs encounter
quotes.text: A lot of times, people go and they ask for a picture or an autograph but this idea of just introducing yourself, saying hello, and thanking someone for something that they've done that impacted you to something that's been a way that my parents have encouraged me to behave in the world and something that I saw them do and saw them model
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A counterintuitive networking model: lead with gratitude and human connection instead of transactional asks.

quotes.topic_title: Apple and iTunes: early days and Steve Jobs encounter
quotes.text: Also, the library was crafted so he would give feedback for months on the content of the library because he would do demos.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A concrete example of how high-stakes product demos are engineered: months of iteration and curation behind what looks effortless.

quotes.topic_title: Apple product model vs modern product management
quotes.text: But yeah, the Apple construct, it's much more of design and engineering led organizations, craftspeople I would say more so than strategy people.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A clear framework for contrasting Apple’s craft-led product org design with strategy/metrics-led models elsewhere.

quotes.topic_title: Apple product model vs modern product management
quotes.text: And it was very much like, "Let's 3D chess our way into what our next move is going to be." Whereas at Apple it was, "Let's tinker and let's craft and let's build and let's see what feels right."
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A memorable mental model contrasting predictive strategy planning with iterative craft-based building.

quotes.topic_title: Apple product model vs modern product management
quotes.text: And then in terms of what it means for product managers on an individual level, so again, there weren't product managers, the closest thing would've been CPMs, technical program managers who help manage the sprints and manage the schedule and listing out what features would happen.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A concrete example of how Apple operationalizes product work without traditional PMs, clarifying role design options.

quotes.topic_title: Apple product model vs modern product management
quotes.text: That was what framed what features you wanted to build and what problems you would put on the table to be solved as opposed to as clear cut metric you're trying to drive forward which is how product management has evolved in another capacity.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance: use narrative/positioning to drive feature selection rather than starting from metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for new creator platforms: solve core problems
quotes.text: I think with any company, solving a real problem is the most important thing.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A foundational product principle for founders building creator platforms: start with a real, acute pain point.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for new creator platforms: solve core problems
quotes.text: I think at the core, every creator needs two things. They need to grow an audience and they need to get paid so that they can make a living.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A simple two-part framework for prioritizing what creator tools must deliver to be valuable.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for new creator platforms: solve core problems
quotes.text: And in some ways, I do think that growing an audience is more important because with that audience, it opens up opportunities in ways that you can monetize.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A counterintuitive prioritization: audience growth can be the primary lever that unlocks monetization options later.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for new creator platforms: solve core problems
quotes.text: So there are lots of problems out there still to be solved for creators. I don't think that this space is nearly solved, done, stick a fork in it. So my advice would be to look at the problems that exist and pick a real one and go for it.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: Encouragement and direction for founders: the creator economy remains under-served, so choose one real problem and execute.

quotes.topic_title: Quick tangent: breakout podcasters and discovery
quotes.text: Have you seen this podcaster, Bobbi, I forget her last name, she rocketed up to the fourth biggest podcast in America with a few episodes of her podcast, she interviews Drake and a few comedians. Have you seen this person?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete example of rapid breakout growth driven by high-profile guests and a small number of episodes.

quotes.topic_title: Quick tangent: breakout podcasters and discovery
quotes.text: I feel like I should, but as we said at the beginning, I'm such a music head, I don't listen to any podcast.
quotes.speaker: Camille Hearst
quotes.context: A reminder that even creator-economy experts may intentionally focus on their own media habits, which can shape what they notice and learn from.
